attributes.title: Stock Take
attributes.description:
After stock take, it was noted that most stock items had nil variations with exception to;

  •        Bread stock had -45 pieces cumulatively

  •        Poly bags had a variance of +1,542pieces cumulatively

  •        Utto had a variance of -0.883 litres

  •        Crates had a variance of +53 pcs

  •        Crate balance as at the time of stock take was 567 pcs

      Details of the findings were as illustrated  in the table below;

Crates:

         As per the system the branch has a total of 3,167 crates. However, the branch has 3,220 crates as per physical count. This means that the branch has an excess of 53 crates physically as compared to the system.
attributes.recommendation:
The branch management should enhance control of stock items so as to eliminate variances noted in poly bags. Adjustment for crates should be done in the system so as to reflect the actual balance in the branch

         Branch sales representative should make a follow up so as to reduce the crate balance in routes and polybags for 600g & 800g Naivas white should be transferred to Dandora 3 as they are currently not in use.
attributes.effect: From the analysis above, most stock items were well controlled with exception to polybags which had variance which maybe as a result of lapses in control.
attributes.remediation_plan: Maintain daily stock take and in cases of variances action and adjustment is done promptly

value: We will make a follow up to ensure stock items with variances are controlled. The crates variance was as a result of 50 yellow crates we received from Main go-down. The excess three crates will be stock in.

Manager and supervisors to enhance controls so as to reduce variances noted and any material variances should be accounted for. The 600g and 800g naivas white poly bags will be transferred to Dandora three to pack bread.
In a prior audit report dated 22nd May 2025 bread stock had a shortfall of -57.25 Loaves, packing material had a surplus of +1,802 pieces and utto experienced a variance of -1.84 units.
Current
A physical stock take was conducted on 16.06.2025 with the aim of establishing whether internal controls were effective and whether physical stock items were matching with those in the SAP system.
Stock items were well controlled with exception to polybags which the branch management should follow up to check what might be causing the excess.
Operations/Production Department
The purpose of this exercise was to compare physical inventory with system  inventory levels to ascertain if there was any variances

attributes.title: Bread Weight Check
attributes.description: From the sample selected, audit noted that all varieties weighed had underweight cases as illustrated in the table below;
attributes.recommendation: Spot checks should be enhanced to ensure all production parameters are followed so as to eliminate cases of underweight.
attributes.effect: Underweight bread dispatched to market exposes the company to risk of penalties if they are intercepted by the weight and measures officials.
attributes.remediation_plan: Enhanced follow up of production procedure up to packing area to check if there are lapses due to human error which need to be rectified or  check if all machines in use are fully working.

value: One of our ovens  had issue with gasket and it has not yet replaced but we will enhance spot checks from the dividing table to packing to ensure set standards on dividing and packing are strictly adhered to
Underweight loaves are not allowed. The manager should follow up with the ticket raised to ensure the gasket is installed so as to control moisture loss
In a prior audit report cases of underweight were as follows; 400gctw-24%, 400g brw-16% and 600gctw-9%
Bread produced and packed in the branch were weighed randomly to determine if bread dispatched to the market was of the correct weight.
From the analysis, cases of underweight were noted in all varieties which implies that there were lapses in follow up
Operations/Production Department
To verify if the final product meets internal and regulatory compliance in regards to weight

attributes.title: Bread Damages Check
attributes.description:
A sample period of 28 days (19 May 2025 to 15 July 2025) was used to analyse bread damages. Audit noted that percentage of average production damages stood at 0.24% of the total production while average market damages was 0.59% of total sales meaning that bread damages were above set limits

         The table below illustrates the findings;

Damages sent to Ingredients

          For the period damages sent to ingredients from 19 May 2025 to 15 June 2025 were less by 22.90kgs or 57.25 pieces of loaves.
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should control bread damages by ensuring all production procedures are being followed and bread produced is of good quality so as to reduce both production and market damages.
attributes.effect: Production and market bread damages were above set limits meaning the company had lost revenue amounting to KES 11,333.16 {[(0.04*1,283)/0.24]*53} and KES 47,382{[(0.09*2,384)/0.59]*53} respectively through excess damages.
attributes.remediation_plan: The branch management should ensure all production and packing procedures are followed

value:
We will enhance control in production area to ensure we produce quality bread hence reduce production damages

Market damagers are on the higher side due to mishandling of bread transfers by sales crew. However, since 1st June 2025 we are arranging 6pcs or 5pcs of 600gm and 800gms varieties respectively.
The branch manager and supervisor should enhance controls in production to achieve bread quality desired so as to minimize damages in the branch.

In a prior audit report average production damages were 0.21% of the total production and had a cost implication of Kshs.3,456.44, market damages were 0.56% of the total sales and had a cost implication Kshs.14,881.86
Current
An analysis of production and market/supermarket damages was done to determine whether they were within the allowed percentage of 0.2% to total production and 0.5% of total sales respectively.
The company  was lost revenue through excess bread damages during the period
Operations/Production Department
The exercise was aimed at checking if whether the branch was operating within set parameters

attributes.title: Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
After examining the records the follow were noted;

  •        Average yield per bag was190.98 loaves per bag.

  •        Utto consumption was at 100%.

  •        Average production was 100.61 bags per day representing of 90.64% target which is 111 bags per day (Branch Capacity)

         The table below illustrates the findings;

         Audit noted that the system recording of raw material usage and loaves produced were matching with those in mixing chart summaries from 19th May 2025 to 15th June 2025.
attributes.recommendation:
On those days the branch run on full capacity, the branch management should ensure production target is achieved and through market promotion within the existing routes to reach out to new customers to boost sales hence increased production

To control remix from escalating, mixing of dough should be slowed down.
attributes.effect: Target production in bags was not achieved meaning the branch’s capacity was underutilized and remixes affects the quality of bread.
attributes.remediation_plan: Control put in place should be maintained

value: In terms of production we produce as per market demand so as to control bread balance and remixes were as a result of oven breakdown
We produced as per market demand. Therefore, at a target achievement of 90.64% we have tried and remix were as a result of oven breakdown.

In a prior audit report Utto consumption stood at 100 %, average yield was 190.91 loaves per bag, average production was 100.52 bags per day this represent 90.56% of the set target of 111 bags and instances of remix noted were 1,898 during the audit period mainly caused by machine breakdown.
Current
Mixing charts and mixing chart summaries from 19th May 2025 to 15th June 2025 were examined to find out the branch’s utto consumption, average yield, cases of remix and summation of totals
Charts and summaries were well documented with details matching those captured in the system.
Operations/Production Department
The exercise was meant to determine  if details captured were correct and if they were matching with those posted in the system

attributes.title: Debtors Analysis
attributes.description: It was observed that outstanding balance was KES 559,205.68. Further audit noted that the account for Patrick Makau was not reconciling as at 16th of June 2025
attributes.recommendation: A follow up should be made to recover the amounts where an individual customer hasn’t paid and reconciliation for each customer should be checked to ensure they are tallying.
attributes.effect: The company is exposed to risk of losing its revenue
attributes.remediation_plan: A follow up should be done and reciliations for those customers should be done on weekly basis. Credit terms should be guided by security for each customer.

value: Currently invoice are generated according to credit limit for customers that’s why we have outstanding debt
We are invoicing customers based on credit limit hence the outstanding balances
Current
Outstanding debts were analysed as at 16th June 2025 to check the magnitude.
Customers reconciliation need to be done from time to time to ensure entries in the system are done accurately when payment is being done so that cases of accounts not agreeing are detected
Finance Department

This test was meant to;

  • Properly assess the value of receivables and potential bad debts.
  • Helps in identifying risky customers who may default.
  • Enables better credit limit and payment term decisions

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description: It was noted that the average production efficiency was 4.26 bags per production worker as illustrated in the table below;
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should allocate production workers as per production target shift wise so as to ensure set efficiency is achieved.
attributes.effect: The branch did not achieve the set production efficiency target meaning that the cost of production in terms of labour was above set budget
attributes.remediation_plan: Implement preventive maintenance schedules for machinery so that to minimize breakdown cases

value: Oven breakdown contributed to a low efficiency. We aim to improve further.
We have been having challenges with oven breakdown which affected our efficiency. However, there’s improvement and we are looking forward to meet set target.
From prior audit report average production efficiency was 4.25 bags per production worker and had a cost implication KES 9,779.40
Current
Production efficiency calculation from 19th May 2025 to 15th June 2025 was done to determine if the production workers hired were achieving the set production efficiency of 4.5 bags per worker.
Labour inefficiencies due to poor planning as a result of periodic maintenance or service of machinery in the branch
Operations/Production Department
To check if each production achieve set target in eight hours and detect inefficiencies or delays in the production line that slow down output or increase costs.

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description: It was noted that the average packing efficiency was 88.13 crates per packer as illustrated below;
attributes.recommendation: Hiring of Packers shift wise should be guided by the number of bags produced in the prior shift. This will enable the branch to achieve set target
attributes.effect: Average packing efficiency was below the set target and this implies that packing cost was above the set budget hence an extra cost to the company
attributes.remediation_plan: Packers should be hired shift wise based on loaves produced in prior shift

value: Some packers are slow hence causing delays in packing. However, there’s an improvement from last audit and we aim to improve further
The manager should control number of packers hired so as to improve on packing efficiency. Compared to prior audit period there’s an improvement
From prior audit report average packing efficiency was 85.47 crates per slicers with accost implication of KES 50,160
Current
Packing efficiency was calculated from 19th May 2025 to 15th June 2025 to determine if the packers hired were achieving the set packing efficiency of 97 crates per packer.
The cost of of packing bread was higher than set target budget
Operations/Production Department
To determine if packers are hired as per number of loaves produced

attributes.title: Vehicle Mileage and Fuel Consumption Analysis
attributes.description: It was noted that five out of seven vehicles in the branch had consumed more fuel than the set limit as illustrated in the table below;
attributes.recommendation: The manager should issue fuel based on the set standard rate for each vehicle to control over consumption
attributes.effect: By consuming more fuel than the distance covered implies that the cost of distribution is above the set target hence an extra cost to the company.
attributes.remediation_plan: Strictly issuing fuel as per distance covered based on set standard rate per kilometre

value: I do issue fuel as per set standard rate. Over consumed fuel in Ruai route was recovered on 17/6/2025
The branch manager should enhance fuel control measures and ensure fuel is issued as per distance covered while adhering to set standard rate
In a prior audit report overall fuel consumption for the fleet was aligning with the established standard rates.

Analysis of fuel consumption was done from 1st to 16th June 2025 to assess the following;

  •          Whether the standard mileage set for each vehicle was being met
Fuel controls need to be enhanced as some vehicles were noted to be over consuming
Transport/Fleet Department
To check whether vehicles fuel consumption was in line with set standard

attributes.title: Bread Return Analysis
attributes.description:
From the analysis a total of 3,077.25 pieces of loaves were returned. If those with torn wrapper  and over supply were excluded it means that 1,485.75(3,077.25-1,590.50-1) were taken as damages hence a loss of revenue worth KES 78,744.75. Below is the illustration of the reasons for return and pieces of loaves in 400gms;

Noted: When the a comparison was made with market returns it was revealed that the two were not matching has the returns which was taken as damages were 1,485.67 pieces while market return damages were 2,383.75 as per Sap system hence a variance of 898 pieces.
attributes.recommendation:
The reason of bread returns should be captured in the system accurately by the sale crew and when the vehicles return from the market the manager should confirm the same.

         Returns should be matching with market return damages when those with torn wrapper or oversupply are reduced from the total as they are good returns.
attributes.effect:
The company is losing sales revenue when bread is returned to the branch due to reasons which can be controlled during production.

The difference between in market return damages implies that capturing of returns was not being done accurately.
attributes.remediation_plan: Demand forecasting models should be improved, tightening production planning, adjusting delivery schedules based on real-time sales data

value: The variance noted in market return or damages verses those as reason was as a result of the sales crew recording deformed bread as torn wrapper.
The manager should receive returns as per the sales crew records and in cases there’s a difference, the same should be reported.
Current
Analysis of all bread retuned to the branch from 19th May 2025 to 16th June 2025 was done to determine the reasons with corresponding sum of bread returned when converted to 400gms.
High return rates are not only causing direct financial losses through wasted inventory and operational costs.
Sales Department

This exercise is meant to:

  • Identify the Reasons for Returns
  • Quantify Financial Impact
  • Adjust production and delivery schedules to better match actual sales patterns and reduce excess returns

attributes.title: Partial Delivery of Orders Analysis
attributes.description: From the analysis 345.75 pieces of loaves for the period were not delivered as per Sap system when converted to 400gms. Below is a tabulation of the findings;
attributes.recommendation: The branch management must ensure that all customer bread orders are delivered accurately without reducing and on time. In instances where delivery delays or supply issues occur, prompt and clear communication should be provided to customers.
attributes.effect: Lost revenue due to missed sales from undelivered orders and repeat customers might switch to competitors if reliability is consistently an issue.
attributes.remediation_plan: The sales team should use sales data, market trends and customer input to predict demand more accurately and ensure adequate stock levels

value: We have been having challenges with returns hence we had to reduce orders.
The manager should not reduce orders without written communication. He should supply as per orders requested
Current
Analysis of partial delivered orders was done form 19th May 2025 to 15th June 2025 to determine the amount of loaves which were not sent to customers.
Partial deliveries  reduces customer satisfaction and potential revenue loss due to incomplete sales
Operations/Production Department
This test is meant to check if all orders placed were being supplied
